Text_Numeracy:
My daughter often gets ear infections. One day, my wife and daughter were out running errands when she was crying so much that my wife found herself rushing to the pediatrician. After a long wait in the office, they finally were seen. The doctor took a quick look, asked a few questions, and very quickly prescribed an antibiotic. 
When they returned home, I asked my daughter how long she had been crying and she answered "a long time." Given the quick diagnosis and prescription I felt that I was dealing with a physician that had fallen into practicing "drive by" medicine rather than taking the time to listen and think. As soon as I had the chance I called the office manager. I had her check the records from her exam. Sure enough, the doctor hadn't made an actual examination. Instead, he had relied on the statement of a crying toddler and had jumped to a conclusion without proper evaluation. 

That same day, the record was amended to show that an examination had occurred, and the antibiotic was never filled.
Text_Anxiety: Nothing. So long as I bring my best friend along. That's good support.

Text_Numeracy: A significant experience that demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues occurred when I learned about the importance of medication management after a friend experienced a severe reaction due to mixing prescriptions improperly. This experience solidified my understanding of how critical it is to stay informed about the medications I take, their potential side effects, and the importance of regular communication with healthcare professionals, even without a primary care physician. Additionally, it highlighted the necessity of maintaining a balanced lifestyle to support overall well-being, which is something I prioritize in my daily routine.

Text_Numeracy: In my first year of college, I took a health course with an adult population teacher.  She asked me to come to the front of the room and when I did she pretended to have a heart attack.  I did everything wrong that I could possibly do.  She asked me if I ever learned CPR before and I told her "NO!"  She told me there wasn't anyone that was even near me.  She asked me if I knew what the signs were and I told her "NO!"  She told me that in the time I wasted, her heart could have stopped and she would have died.  Ever since then, I carry the "signs of a heart attack" card in my wallet and I have learned CPR.  I never want to be in that situation again.

Text_Numeracy: I was at the hospital visiting a friend who was having knee surgery, As we were waiting for the doctor to show up there was an older gentleman in the waiting room who was very nervous about having his surgery. His nervousness had nothing to do with it being in a hospital but rather it was about having a surgery that he did not fully understand and trusted. I sat and talked to him about his procedure and the wonderful doctors that he would be needing. I share with him my personal experiences of having surgery at that same hospital. After calming his nerves he was called into the next room for his pre-op interview and afterwards he again approached me and thanked me and told me that he was no longer nervous.

Text_Numeracy: This past summer my wife noticed some unusual swelling in her left foot. After noticing it didn't go down overnight, we went to Urgent Care. They performed an ultrasound and found a DVT. She was put on Coumadin for the DVT. Since she was now on Coumadin, urine tests were required to monitor the dose she was on. One of the test results was out of range and reported to her doctor. They again performed another common blood test. It was found that she had some kind of liver disease which would require a visit to a liver specialist. When the disease was confirmed, she was informed that we could not go on a holiday cruise that we had planned due to the fact that her health could have complications while being away. We would get a full refund, but we would still need to get away for a holiday.
Text_Anxiety: When visiting the doctor's office, what makes me most anxious is the fear of receiving a negative result. I think this is normal but hopefully a rare experience.

Prescribed RX helps the test results, but I never receive the RX as the test, visit or lab is always wrong.

I may only have 15 minutes of his time and he might not really even have time to read my chart.  In those cases, I make up my mind myself.  Sometimes the insurance companies won't allow me to use the doctor that I prefer, so that I have to make less informed decisions too.

Text_Numeracy: In high school I was very active and thought myself very healthy.  I got pericarditis in my sophomore year. Eventually we found a doctor who knew what it was and gave me medication to reduce the swelling of the pericardium.  It took 6 months to heal and I kept my self active during that time.

Text_Numeracy: A few years back, I collapsed and fainted while watching my son play soccer. I knew I had been not drinking enough water (even though it was late afternoon and not particularly hot outside). I also knew I was feeling odd for a while- lightheaded and weak. I went to urgent care a couple of days later, and sure enough, my BP was low. The doctor said it was probably due to dehydration and told me to drink more fluids. I told him I already did, and that my knees had also been hurting a lot ever since I started exercising more. He took blood tests and called me a couple of days later to tell me that I was also critically low in potassium (a side effect of dehydration, along with low BP).

Text_Numeracy: When I lived in South Korea, a friend broke her foot while we were hiking. She insisted that she wanted me to drive her to the hospital, even though the hospital was at least 45 minutes away- she didn't want to as for help from any other friends who could have. While driving, I asked her about the injury symptoms. I knew that we were most likely going to an orthopedic, but there are two types of orthopedic- one specializes is post-trauma or tendon/ligament injury; one is for congenital forming or deformity. This discussion revealed that my friend had broken her foot before, and the old break had healed incorrectly. So, once arrived at the orthopedic unit, I suggested that we ask specifically to see the doctor who specialized in post-trauma injuries, she agreed, and he admitted that my diagnosis was correct and was happy to see her.
Text_Anxiety: I dislike the wait and the sterile atmosphere. The check-in people are usually perky, and I am not perky. I also hate the inquiring and probing, and the invasive procedures, and the bills.

Since maintaining my health is a top priority, I actively seek out reliable sources of information to guide my decisions related to my prescriptions and overall wellness. Although I engage regularly with healthcare professionals, I always strive to educate myself about my medications, any possible side effects, and how my physical activity can complement my health regimen. This proactive approach allows me to make informed health decisions that align with my goals.

Text_Numeracy: I was diagnosed with breast cancer. I learned about the disease and treatments to help me! All cancer doctors, oncologists, surgeons, etc. are very informed about everything! The know everything about the disease!

Text_Numeracy: When Covid hit in March 2020, grandparents were very high risk. My grandpa led a very active lifestyle, so it was really easy for me to track their changing health. Luckily, their conditions stayed stable.

Text_Numeracy: In 2020, my daughter developed what was finally diagnosed as spinal stenosis. The first time the doctor said it, I thought I heard him wrong - I never heard those two words before. The more I listened to him, I figured that the first half of his diagnosis was the end result of what I was saying in the second half. Through my daughter's ten-year dance career I became accustomed to hearing what types of injuries/damage dancers can develop that could limit their careers. As the doctor explained my daughter's condition, he kept mentioning things I had heard from differnt ballet teachers over the years. Because of that, I could align what the doctor was saying with the risks associated with intense dancing.
Text_Anxiety: What makes me feel most anxious or worried when visiting the doctor's office is the fear of being diagnosed with something terrible. Finding something wrong and fearing the numerous possibilities of treatment that exist.
Text_TrustPhys: More than any thing I think my doctor really cares. He takes the necessary time to really listen.  I've never felt rushed.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel I am capable of understanding the basic health information needed to make appropriate health decisions. I oftentimes educate myself or ask questions to clarification.

Text_Numeracy: I remember a time when I was dealing with some side effects from a new prescription medication. I did a lot of research on the potential interactions and common symptoms associated with it. I also reached out to various forums and support groups online to gather insights from others who had similar experiences. Armed with that knowledge, I was able to have a well-informed discussion with my psychologist about my concerns, which helped us navigate my medication regimen more effectively. This experience reinforced my understanding of how crucial it is to stay informed about health issues, especially when managing multiple prescriptions.
Text_Anxiety: I wouldn’t say I feel anxiety when meeting doctors, but there is certainly a sense of unease. I think it comes from the anticipation of what they might say about my prescriptions or health. I worry about how they perceive my reliance on medication, and whether they'll consider my lifestyle choices—like my physical activity—to be enough. There’s a nagging concern about whether I’m managing my health in the best way possible, even if I generally feel that my well-being is good. Overall, it's more about hoping for positive feedback rather than anxiety itself.
Text_TrustPhys: I don’t have a primary care physician, which makes it hard for me to establish a trusting relationship with any doctor. I frequently visit various specialists or psychologists instead, so I tend to rely on their expertise without forming a deep connection. I appreciate their knowledge and professionalism, but I sometimes feel apprehensive about lingering doubts regarding their understanding of my overall health, given my complex medication regimen. Trust can be difficult when I don’t have a consistent point of contact to track my medical history and needs comprehensively.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I believe I have a good capacity to obtain and process health information, especially given my regular engagement with different healthcare providers. I actively seek out information about my medications and health concerns, which helps me understand my treatment options. However, I sometimes feel overwhelmed by the variety and complexity of information available, which can make it challenging to make the best decisions for my health. Overall, while I’m capable, there is room for improvement in how I navigate and synthesize all that information effectively.
